data.sampled: The name of the option strategy being implemented is a Bull Put Spread. This involves selling an out-of-the-money (OTM) put and buying another OTM put to create a net credit position, while also purchasing an out-of-the-money (OTM) call and selling an OTM call to offset some of the cost. The goal of this strategy is to profit from time decay if both options expire worthless, or to benefit from rising prices above the higher strike price. However, there is unlimited risk below the lower strike price and limited reward potential due to the premium paid for the bullish calls.

data.sampled: The option strategy being implemented is called a bearish diagonal spread or a calendar spread. This involves selling an out-of-the money (OTM) put and buying an OTM put with a lower exercise price, as well as selling an OTM call and buying an ITM call with a higher exercise price. The goal is to profit from time decay on both options sold while benefiting from potential volatility expansion towards the ITM call's strike price.

data.sampled: This appears to be an "Iron Condor" option trading strategy. The Iron Condor involves selling one or more out-of-the-money options and buying other options at different strikes around the sold ones. In this case, the trader has sold two puts (at $200 and $175 strike prices) and bought two calls (at $200 and $220 strike prices). By doing so, they aim to benefit from the difference between the premiums collected on the sold options and the cost of the purchased options if the stock's price stays within a certain range by expiration. However, it carries some risk as well since the strategy can result in losses if the underlying asset moves significantly above or below the sold options' strike prices.

data.sampled: This is an example of a "buy-write" or "covered write" options trading strategy, where the trader buys stock and simultaneously writes (i.e., sells) options on that stock to generate additional income. The puts give the holder the right to sell their shares at a certain price, while the calls give them the right to buy more shares at a certain price. In this case, the trader has sold one put option with a strike price of $17 per share, bought another put option with a strike price of $12 per share, sold a call option with a strike price of $17 per share, and bought a call option with a strike price of $22 per share. By combining these transactions, the trader can potentially profit from any movement in either direction of the underlying asset's price as well as earn premiums received from writing options.

data.sampled: This appears to be an example of a bear put spread strategy. The seller of the puts hopes that the stock will stay below both strike prices (the breakeven point) and gain the premium paid by buyers while potentially losing out on some potential upside gains from holding the underlying asset. Meanwhile, the buyer of the calls expects that the stock won't rise above their strike price but still gets the premium paid by sellers. The risk for either party is limited, except if the stock goes significantly beyond or below the range formed between the two strike prices.

data.sampled: This appears to be an Iron Condor options trading strategy. It involves selling two out-of-the-money (OTM) puts and buying one OTM put and one ITM (in-the-money) put on the other side, as well as selling one OTM call and buying one ITM call on the other side. The goal is to generate income through premium received from selling options while limiting potential losses if the underlying stock moves significantly either up or down before expiration.

data.sampled: This appears to be an example of a bull put spread, also known as a horizontal debit spread or a bearish credit spread. A bull put spread involves selling one put option and buying another put option with a lower strike price, both options having the same expiration date. In this case, the trader has sold a put option with a higher strike price (102) while simultaneously purchasing a second put option with a lower strike price (98). The difference between the sale and purchase prices forms the net premium received by the trader, which can serve as a source of income or profit if executed correctly.
